channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Hole in North Korean Sanctions Big Enough for Coal, Oil and Used Pianos
item.description: When the United Nations approved tougher restrictions, it was understood they would work only if China complied. So far, border enforcement has been spotty.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG
item.media:description: Sinuiju, in North Korea, lies across the Yalu River from the Chinese border town of Dandong. Sanctions approved in March against North Korea appear to have had little impact on its trade with China.

item.title: Video: Terrorism and Migrant Crisis Propel Europe’s Far-Right Movements
item.description: Attacks in Brussels and Paris, as well as a surge of migrants, have left parties like France’s National Front with the political winds at their back.
item.dc:creator: BEN C. SOLOMON, TAIGE JENSEN, STEFANIA ROUSSELLE and LESLYE DAVIS

item.title: Gail Minglana Martinez, Mother in Air Force Family, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: All six members of her family were wounded in the attack on Brussels Airport. The others, her officer husband and four children, remain hospitalized.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Gail Minglana Martinez in a photo from social media.

item.title: Dilma Rousseff Loses Support From Key Part of Brazilian Coalition
item.description: The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party’s leaders voted to split from the president’s party, a move that could increase the likelihood of her being impeached.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:description: Senator Romero Jucá announcing the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party’s split with President Dilma Rousseff’s Workers’ Party at a meeting in Brasília.

item.title: Campaign Season’s Anti-China Tone Is Likely to Cloud Meeting With Obama
item.description: As President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China prepare to meet, Beijing is viewing the vitriol from candidates like Donald J. Trump as a gauge of American intentions.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Security agents walked alongside the car of China’s president, Xi Jinping, as he arrived Wednesday at Joint Base Andrews, near Washington, to attend the nuclear security summit meeting.

item.title: Paul Pontallier, Who Gave New Life to a Bordeaux Estate, Dies at 59
item.description: Mr. Pontallier helped restore Château Margaux, a celebrated name in the history of wine, to pre-eminence and served as its passionate embodiment.
item.dc:creator: ERIC ASIMOV
item.media:description: Paul Pontallier helped restore Château Margaux, a celebrated name in the history of wine, to pre-eminence and served as its passionate embodiment.

item.title: Mohawk, a 13-Year-Old Lion, Is Killed by Kenya Wildlife Rangers
item.description: The male lion was shot by wildlife officials several times after he knocked a man off a motorcycle near Nairobi National Park.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Colombia’s Second-Largest Rebel Group Joins Peace Talks With Government
item.description: The announcement by the National Liberation Army, known as the E.L.N., raised hopes that the end of a 50-year conflict could be near.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Libya’s Unity Government Defies Air Blockade to Reach Tripoli
item.description: Members of the presidency council arrived by boat from Tunisia, defying a blockade led by rival groups and hoping to end a political stalemate.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Fayez Serraj, the Libyan prime minister-designate, said Wednesday at a news conference in Tripoli that he would broker a cease-fire among Libya’s myriad factions and confront the Islamic state.

item.title: Frenchman Plotting ‘Imminent’ Attack Is Charged With Terrorism
item.description: Reda Kriket, 34, who was arrested last week in a suburb of Paris, has a long history of criminal and jihadist activity, the Paris prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and LILIA BLAISE
item.media:description: The corner of Rue Max Roos and Rue Maurice Ombiaux in the Schaerbeek area of Brussels on March 22 after the attacks at an airport and a subway station.

item.title: U.N. Urges Countries to Take in 480,000 Syrian Refugees
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, opening a conference in Geneva, called for “an exponential increase in global solidarity” over the next three years.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: The secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, center, met with Syrian refugees during his visit last week to a camp in Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley.

item.title: Erdogan’s Attempt to Suppress German Satire Has the Opposite Effect
item.description: A video by the comedy show “extra3” that pokes fun at President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey had attracted more than three million views by Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Kayhan Ozer/Turkish Presidential Palace, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey is the subject of a German-made satirical video deriding his treatment of journalists, the opposition and his country’s Kurdish minority.

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa to Fight Parole for Killer of Anti-Apartheid Activist
item.description: The government said it would appeal the release of Janusz Walus, who had been serving a life sentence for the murder of Chris Hani in 1993.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: World Briefing: European Court Backs Britain in 2005 Subway Killing by Police
item.description: The decision is likely to end the fight by relatives of the shooting victim, a Brazilian misidentified as a suicide bomber, to have British officers charged.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Tata Steel Plans to Sell British Plants, Threatening 15,000 Jobs
item.description: Profits at the Indian-owned Tata Steel have been squeezed by cheap Chinese imports, and the company suggested that it would consider closing its plants if no buyer came forward.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Seven thousand jobs are at stake at Britain’s largest steel plant, the Port Talbot works in Wales.

item.title: Israel Polarized Over Soldier Who Killed Wounded Palestinian
item.description: While many Israelis denounced the shooting, others expressed outrage at their military’s high command for prosecuting the soldier, calling him a hero.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israelis demonstrated outside a military court in Kiryat Malakhi on Tuesday to support a soldier who was suspended after being caught on video shooting a wounded Palestinian assailant in the head.

item.title: Is Europe Safe for Travelers? Yes, Experts Say, but Here Are Some Tips
item.description: American tourists seem unfazed by recent terror attacks, but travel experts do suggest some basic precautions.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WORKMAN
item.media:description: Travelers at Kennedy International Airport in March. Officials advise that when traveling abroad, give a copy of your itinerary to family members or friends.

item.title: Businessman and Dictator Face Off as Congo Lurches Toward Abyss
item.description: Analysts say the tycoon Moïse Katumbi is best positioned to win Congo’s next election. There is just one problem: There might not be an election.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Moïse Katumbi was surrounded by supporters as he left a church in Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of Congo. Analysts say Mr. Katumbi is best positioned to win Congo’s next election — if there is an election.

item.title: Panjwai Journal: To Feed Hungry Minds, Afghans Seed a Ravaged Land With Books
item.description: A volunteer organization founded by a teenager has worked to reopen schools and create libraries in some of the Afghan provinces hardest hit by war.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matiullah Wesa, center, his brother Atta Muhammad and their nieces in the library Mr. Wesa established three years ago in their family home in Spinbaldak, in southern Afghanistan. Mr. Muhammad is the library’s caretaker. Mr. Wesa has established several other libraries across the country.

item.title: EgyptAir Hijacking Suspect Says He Acted Out of Desperation
item.description: In a court appearance, Seif Eldin Mustafa faced numerous charges in connection with the EgyptAir flight that was diverted to Cyprus.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
